issue.title: Interop with stock/non-PQ openssh failing
issue.body:
When logging in from OpenSSH_7.9p1 client to OQS-OpenSSH_7.9-2020-08_p1 server there is a connection error:
```
...
debug1: kex: algorithm: curve25519-sha256
debug1: kex: host key algorithm: ssh-ed25519
debug1: kex: server->client cipher: chacha20-poly1305@openssh.com MAC: <implicit> compression: none
debug1: kex: client->server cipher: chacha20-poly1305@openssh.com MAC: <implicit> compression: none
...
debug3: receive packet: type 60
debug1: Server accepts key: /home/vt/.ssh/id_ed25519 ED25519 ...
debug3: sign_and_send_pubkey: ED25519 ...
debug3: sign_and_send_pubkey: signing using ssh-ed25519
debug3: send packet: type 50
debug3: receive packet: type 52
debug1: Authentication succeeded (publickey).
Authenticated to 10.4.0.61 ([10.4.0.61]:22).
debug1: channel 0: new [client-session]
debug3: ssh_session2_open: channel_new: 0
debug2: channel 0: send open
debug3: send packet: type 90
debug1: Entering interactive session.
debug1: pledge: network
Bad packet length 496648.
debug3: send packet: type 1
ssh_dispatch_run_fatal: Connection to 10.4.0.61 port 22: Connection corrupted

```
When logging in from OQS-OpenSSH_7.9-2020-08_p1 client to the same server there is no error.

comment.body:
> So, problem only if OQS algorithms are enabled on the server side.

Thanks for that confirmation -- that then might explain things: As soon as one of the "crazy big" algorithms is enabled, the larger --and incompatible-- buffer size might be triggered. I need to read up on the SSH protocol to understand if/when this occurs (maybe the server proposes them all to the client and in so doing the problem hits? Maybe @dstebila or @xvzcf you already know?). Might disabling/removing Sphincs and Rainbow host keys already suffice (?) to achieve your stated goal:

> client users should be able to choose to connect with OQS (if they enable it) or using generic algorithms and generic OpenSSH clients

to which I fully agree.

Now, after having built also the old (7.9) `OQS-openssh` locally I still fail to reproduce the error you are reporting, though: I still can connect OK (albeit very slowly) with a stock ssh to an OQS-sshd... So, could I ask you which exact platform you are using? Do you possibly have a docker image with which to reproduce things _exactly_? Or could you share all steps/the script that led to the behaviour reported? Thanks in advance.

issue.title: Import BIKE Round-3 Additional code
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Import BIKE Round-3 code from the "Additional implementation" available at https://github.com/awslabs/bike-kem.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Addresses  #887

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: @baentsch thanks for your help! I added the sha256sum's of the KATs (after verifying that the KATs are the same as in the BIKE repository). And I also tried to fix a build issue with older compilers which don't support the "vpclmulqdq" flag.

comment.body: @dkostic can you provide a reference for the upstream KATs? I don't see matching values in the NIST submission package, but perhaps I'm overlooking something.

issue.title: Update oqs-kem-info.md
issue.body:
I think there may have been a bug in the script that was used to generate this table. The algorithm identifiers in this table match those in [this previous spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/12YarzaNv3XQNLnvDsWLlRKwtZFhRrDdWf36YlzwrPeg/edit#gid=0) which had all Round 2 labels. 

This table should match the data that the old spreadsheet had, so I manually changed the labels on this table to use Round 2 labels so that when new Round 3 labels are added in the future they won't conflict.

issue.title: Update oqs-kem-info.md
issue.body:
I think there may have been a bug in the script that was used to generate this table. The algorithm identifiers in this table match those in [this previous spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/12YarzaNv3XQNLnvDsWLlRKwtZFhRrDdWf36YlzwrPeg/edit#gid=0) which had all Round 2 labels. 

This table should match the data that the old spreadsheet had, so I manually changed the labels on this table to use Round 2 labels so that when new Round 3 labels are added in the future they won't conflict.

comment.body:
> Let's use the ID's that we have in our s2n PR.
> 
> ```
> #define TLS_PQ_KEM_GROUP_ID_X25519_BIKE_L1_R3       0x2F37
> #define TLS_PQ_KEM_GROUP_ID_SECP256R1_BIKE_L1_R3    0x2F38
> #define TLS_PQ_KEM_GROUP_ID_X25519_KYBER_512_R3     0x2F39
> #define TLS_PQ_KEM_GROUP_ID_SECP256R1_KYBER_512_R3  0x2F3A
> ```

Okay, I've added these to the table in #313. I'm going to close this PR, please do further discussion on #313.

issue.title: Support more NIDs in KEM table
issue.body:
This adds extra fields in the generate.yml file to track

- extra hybrid curves (e.g., x25519)
- past NID identifiers

Replaces #311.  Fixes #312.

If we are happy with this general approach, then before this is merged we will need to:

- [ ] Fill in the remaining Kyber Round 2 previous NIDs
- [ ] Set new NIDs for Kyber Round 3 (using values from s2n, if they've been set)

comment.body:
BIKE has changed their naming scheme in their Round 3 submission. Before it's scheme was `bike1l1fo`, now it is just `bikel1`. Also, I'm not sure if you want to include the BIKE version number of `4.1` or leave it as `NIST Round 3 submission`.


```
| Family         | Implementation Version   | Variant         |   Claimed NIST Level | PQ-only Code Point   | Hybrid Elliptic Curve   | Hybrid Code Point   |
| BIKE           | 4.1 (NIST Round 3)       | bikel1          |                    1 | 0x0237               | x25519                  | 0x2F37              |
| BIKE           | 4.1 (NIST Round 3)       | bikel1          |                    1 | 0x0238               | secp256_r1              | 0x2F38              |
| CRYSTALS-Kyber | NIST Round 3 submission  | kyber512        |                    1 | 0x0239               | x25519                  | 0x2F39              |
| CRYSTALS-Kyber | NIST Round 3 submission  | kyber512        |                    1 | 0x023A               | secp256_r1              | 0x2F3A              |
```

issue.title: Interop with stock/non-PQ openssh failing
issue.body:
When logging in from OpenSSH_7.9p1 client to OQS-OpenSSH_7.9-2020-08_p1 server there is a connection error:
```
...
debug1: kex: algorithm: curve25519-sha256
debug1: kex: host key algorithm: ssh-ed25519
debug1: kex: server->client cipher: chacha20-poly1305@openssh.com MAC: <implicit> compression: none
debug1: kex: client->server cipher: chacha20-poly1305@openssh.com MAC: <implicit> compression: none
...
debug3: receive packet: type 60
debug1: Server accepts key: /home/vt/.ssh/id_ed25519 ED25519 ...
debug3: sign_and_send_pubkey: ED25519 ...
debug3: sign_and_send_pubkey: signing using ssh-ed25519
debug3: send packet: type 50
debug3: receive packet: type 52
debug1: Authentication succeeded (publickey).
Authenticated to 10.4.0.61 ([10.4.0.61]:22).
debug1: channel 0: new [client-session]
debug3: ssh_session2_open: channel_new: 0
debug2: channel 0: send open
debug3: send packet: type 90
debug1: Entering interactive session.
debug1: pledge: network
Bad packet length 496648.
debug3: send packet: type 1
ssh_dispatch_run_fatal: Connection to 10.4.0.61 port 22: Connection corrupted

```
When logging in from OQS-OpenSSH_7.9-2020-08_p1 client to the same server there is no error.

comment.body:
Further experiments show that when I disable any one of the following keys `Bad packet length` error disappears and I can ssh successfully: `ssh_host_p256_rainbowiclassic_key`, `ssh_host_rsa3072_rainbowiclassic_key`.
Disabling `*sphincs*` keys does not affect the connection. So, "bad" keys are `rainbow`.

Also, my sshd build has disabled in `oqs-template/generate.yml` — RAINBOW_III_CLASSIC and RAINBOW_V_CLASSIC, because these keys are very slow to keygen (many minutes) making sshd start unacceptably long.

We build using rpmbuild system. There is my repo: http://git.altlinux.org/people/vt/packages/?p=openssh.git;a=shortlog;h=refs/heads/openquantumsafe
Perhaps like this, it could be reproduced manually:
```
5.11.21-un-def-alt1:~# docker run --rm -it alt:sisyphus bash
[root@bbf090845480 /]# apt-get update
[root@bbf090845480 /]# apt-get install -y rpm-build git libssl-devel liboqs-devel su \
         pam_userpass-devel zlib-devel libkrb5-devel libaudit-devel libedit-devel \
         libselinux-devel python3-module-jinja2 python3-module-yaml
[root@bbf090845480 ~]# useradd builder
[root@bbf090845480 ~]# su - builder
[builder@bbf090845480 ~]$ mkdir -p /home/builder/RPM/SOURCES/
[builder@bbf090845480 ~]$ git clone git://git.altlinux.org/people/vt/packages/openssh.git openquantumsafe-openssh-7.9p1.202008
[builder@bbf090845480 ~]$ tar cf /home/builder/RPM/SOURCES/openquantumsafe-openssh-7.9p1.202008.tar openquantumsafe-openssh-7.9p1.202008
[builder@bbf090845480 ~]$ rpmbuild -bc openquantumsafe-openssh-7.9p1.202008/openssh.spec
```
It will execute commands from `%prep` and `%build` sections of the `.spec` with sources utarred in `/home/builder/RPM/BUILD` and build artifacts in `/home/builder/RPM/BUILD/openquantumsafe-openssh-7.9p1.202008`.
```
[builder@bbf090845480 ~]$ cd /home/builder/RPM/BUILD
[builder@bbf090845480 BUILD]$ find -name sshd -perm -1 -ls
 21502742   3624 -rwxr-xr-x   1 builder  builder   3707632 Jun  7 22:28 ./openquantumsafe-openssh-7.9p1.202008/sshd
```

> BIKE has changed their naming scheme in their Round 3 submission. Before it's scheme was `bike1l1fo`, now it is just `bikel1`. Also, I'm not sure if you want to include the BIKE version number of `4.1` or leave it as `NIST Round 3 submission`.
> 
> ```
> | Family         | Implementation Version   | Variant         |   Claimed NIST Level | PQ-only Code Point   | Hybrid Elliptic Curve   | Hybrid Code Point   |
> | BIKE           | 4.1 (NIST Round 3)       | bikel1          |                    1 | 0x0237               | x25519                  | 0x2F37              |

@xvzcf How would you handle variant renaming in the .yml file?
